III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & Rule 400.4126
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth J went Absent With Out Leave (AWOL) four times in one
month implying inadequate staff supervision.
Investigation Documents reviewed:
I was assigned this investigation on 3/11/24 with the Complainant
listed as anonymous.
I reviewed Wolverine Center’s Truancy Prevention Policy revised
3/1/24 which indicates the following: When a youth AWOLs, staff
are to make efforts to verbally redirect, offer support and present
alternatives to truanting. Direct care staff will walk outdoors with
the youth encouraging him to return but will not physically
intervene. When line of sight is lost, direct care staff will notify the
supervisor on duty. The supervisor will ensure law enforcement is
notified.
I reviewed incident reports confirming Youth J AWOLed from the
facility four times. Each incident report was reviewed and signed
by the Chief Administrator (CA). Precipitating events ranged from
Youth J’s unwillingness to follow staff directions to unwillingness
to wait for a desired recreational activity.
The incident report on 2/15/24 indicated Youth J was redirected
and followed outdoors by staff, the supervisor was notified, and a
missing person’s report was filed.
The incident report on 3/1/24 indicated Youth J ran outdoors with
a peer, was followed by staff, verbally redirected and a missing
person’s report was filed with police.
2

The incident report on 3/7/24 indicated Youth J and other youth
refused to go to their rooms at bedtime, walked outdoors, were
redirected, followed by staff and returned before a missing
person’s report could be filed.
The incident report on 3/10/24 indicated Youth J and other youths
went AWOL, were redirected by staff, staff lost line of sight and a
missing person’s report was filed.
Interviews:
I contacted Youth J’s Foster Care Worker and notified him of the
investigation assignment.
When Government Worker 1 and I arrived at the school, an
unidentified adult announced to Youth J in front of other youths
that “CPS wanted to talk to him.” Youth J’s Foster Care Worker
was also at the school and Government Worker 1 invited him to sit
in on the interview.
Initially Youth J refused to talk to investigators. After some
encouragement from Government Worker 1, he entered the
interview room on crutches with his left foot bandaged.
I interviewed Youth J jointly with Government Worker 1 and Foster
Care Worker present. Government Worker 1 asked him about his
most recent AWOL on 3/10/24. At first, he shrugged and could
not say why he left the building. Then he stated he left because
he was upset that his own behaviors make him ineligible for
outings. Youth J said when he leaves without permission, there
are two to three staff monitoring four youths. He said he always
AWOLs alone around 2pm and staff follow him and “say stuff,”
which is inconsistent with reports indicating Youth J went AWOL
twice with other youths between 6pm – 8pm.
I interviewed Youth Z at the facility jointly with Government Worker
1. He said he has gone AWOL but never with Youth J. “Staff kept
telling us to come back.” Asked if there are consequences for
going AWOL, Youth Z responded, “Can’t go on outings.” I asked
what would keep him and other youths from going AWOL. He
said he did not know.
I interviewed Supervisor jointly with Government Worker 1. He
has worked at the facility for 33 years. Supervisor was asked
what staff do when a youth leaves without permission. He said
staff follow them outdoors unless it is dark, unsafe or would leave
the building out of ratio. Staff verbally redirect the youth(s) back
3

and maintain contact with the supervisor on duty. Supervisor said
he sometimes drives around the neighborhood looking for them.
“Kids will run and hide behind bushes and lots and throw stuff at
staff. One threw a brick at the agency vehicle.” Supervisor
believes most youths that AWOL do it because they do not want
to be in residential placement.
Asked specifically about Youth J, Supervisor said he has pushed
past staff, pushed staff to the ground, picked up objects outdoors
and pretended he would cut himself if staff came near him. “We
cannot block the doors because this is an open facility. There’s
not too much else we can do…Youth J will destroy property. He
has broken the staff badge scanner inside the building and glass
block windows on the building outdoors. In terms of his most
recent AWOL on 3/10/24, Supervisor said Youth J and others
were playing outdoors monitored by two staff and left the property
together for no apparent reason. “Staff notified me. Staff 1
followed Youth J and lost sight of him after 15 minutes. I write the
police reports (at the facility) and a staff person takes it to the
Detroit Police Department 5th Precinct.
I interviewed Staff 1 via phone on 3/18/24. He has only worked at
the facility for three weeks. Staff 1 did not recall any specific
details surrounding Youth J’s AWOL on 3/10/24. When youths
AWOL, he said staff verbally encourage them to return and follow
them until they lose sight of the youth.
I interviewed Chief Administrator (CA) jointly with Government
Worker 1. She reviewed the incident reports and affirmed that
staff followed the written procedures for each of Youth J’s AWOLs.
Government Worker 1 had no findings.
Analysis When Youth J went AWOL, there was no indication of inadequate
staff supervision.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
